author: kidney83
body:
CS are one of the true Endpoint Detection and Response (EDR) vendors. It goes way beyond traditional antivirus (McAfee, Symantec, Trend, etc). 

The next gen endpoint protection vendors focus primarily on behaviour based detection rather than signatures. Collecting a large number of contextual metrics and then correlating these to detect indicators of compromise and prevent them effectively.

CS are one of the best out there. Superb marketing. Lots of hype. Only vendor I've seen that goes toe-to-toe is Cybereason. They are not listed yet though, but keep an eye out.

author: Engrish_Bulldog
body: Endpoint Detection/Response and NGAV actually but yeah close enough.  They're honestly the best player in the EDR space right now. I'm a chief information security officer in NYC and all of my peers are dropping traditional AV like Symantec for CS because it allows a smaller team to do more. The tool is an incredible force multiplier if you have a SOC that knows what to do with it.

author: dreybaybay
body:
Of course fundamentals matter. By knowing tech I mean I’m in the industry and I know what products are best and how well they’re doing compared to others well before you see it in top line results - and definitely before wall st. who don’t use the tech on the ground and see the trends competitively. There is no doubt that provides an edge on where to place your bets across B2B tech if you’re competing, partnering, and integrating with the other players in the space and through your network. 

Great example is new Relic. Everyone in the industry new they were getting killed way before their price halved because of architectural decisions and pricing mechanics changes. Everyone knew it was two players eating their lunch (stocks which have since some very well).
Same with Symantec and Oracle and all their adjacent competitors. 

There is just no way I could know that about energy and telecom at this juncture.

Maybe I can get there but hard for me to make big bets on who is differentiating themselves when I have no idea how these guys differentiate their products and services.  

And I guess just trying to figure out if it’s worth investing time to understand another space as intimately without living and breathing it the way I have with tech. 

Edit: typos

author: Ifuqinhateit
body: EMC, Symantec and CA are no longer ticker symbols, so, don’t kid yourself. Big companies go away. Cloud transformation is really just starting and you really have no idea what is going to happen over the next 10 years. It used to take five years just to implement an important enterprise software solution at an F100 and fully unwinding it was insanely difficult and took a long time. It was even difficult at smaller enterprises. Now, not so much. I never said cloud companies don’t have good revenue streams or they aren’t poised for growth, I’ve said all along that it isn’t as sticky as it used to be. The decay can happen just as quickly as the growth.

author: Ifuqinhateit
body: Research Brodcom’s acquisitions of CA and Symantec. It’ll tell you all you need to know.

author: CoalFlavored
body:
I’ve done quite a bit of work in the last month. All with dividends are enrolled in DRIP. In descending order by allocation -

AAPL 23.57%
TXN 21.47%
KO 17.78%
NET 13.60%
ARKF 8.57%
Cash 6.42%
VNQ 3.63%
VDC 2.48%
BOXL 2.48%

I guess I’m going for a moderately aggressive profile. AAPL, TXN, and KO for long term growth; NET, ARKF, and BOXL for pure speculation; VNQ and VDC for stability. I’m torn right now between focusing on continuing to load on more speculation (I’m 26), or to rush 100 KO shares to sell covered calls on for passive income and to essentially end up wheeling. Thoughts?
